metadata.source: CCHMC Pocket Docs - Bugs and Drugs 2024
metadata.description: Disease-specific antibiotic recommendations from Cincinnati Children's Hospital

diseases.name: Ehrlichiosis/Anaplasmosis
diseases.notes: Suspect if febrile, flu-like illness without rash in April-Sept. Leukopenia & thrombocytopenia common. PO preferred.

diseases.name: Fever and Neutropenia
diseases.notes: High-risk or ill-appearing patients add vancomycin

diseases.name: Lyme Disease
diseases.notes: Early rash (erythema migrans), carditis, facial nerve palsy, meningitis/encephalitis, arthritis

diseases.name: CLABSI - CoNS
diseases.notes: Consider removing catheter. Strongly consider consulting ID.

diseases.name: CLABSI - Enterococcus

alternatives.indication: E. faecalis vanA/B Positive or E. faecium

diseases.notes: Pending antibiotic susceptibilities. Strongly consider consulting ID.

diseases.name: CLABSI - Candida
diseases.notes: Remove catheter. Treat for 14 days minimum after first negative blood culture.

diseases.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diseases.notes: Recommended for ALL age groups. Suspect if fever, rash (95%), petechiae spreading from distal to central, thrombocytopenia, hyponatremia.

diseases.name: Septic Shock / Bacteremia
diseases.notes: Obtain blood cultures. Replete intravascular volume, maximize O2 delivery.

diseases.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome - Staphylococcal
diseases.notes: Most often associated with toxin-producing organisms at mucosal site.

diseases.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome - Streptococcal
diseases.notes: More likely to cause invasive disease at deep site. Seek deep site infection aggressively.

diseases.name: Bacterial Meningitis
diseases.notes: Gram stain to expand (not contract) empiric therapy. Add vancomycin when S. pneumoniae suspected.

diseases.name: Meningitis Prophylaxis for Contacts
diseases.notes: For suspected and confirmed cases of N. meningitidis. All contacts in same house for >=4 hours.

diseases.name: VP Shunt Infection
diseases.notes: Always involve Neurosurgery. Aerobic/anaerobic shunt culture with routine cell counts & chemistries.

diseases.name: Bacterial Conjunctivitis
diseases.notes: Do not treat any conjunctivitis with topical steroids.

diseases.name: HSV Conjunctivitis
diseases.notes: Can be sight-threatening. Refer to ophthalmologist immediately. 30-50% recurrence in 2 years.

diseases.name: Orbital Cellulitis
diseases.notes: Complication of sinusitis. Proptosis, limited EOM, chemosis, eyelid edema, pain. Surgical drainage may be needed.

diseases.name: Preseptal Cellulitis
diseases.notes: Infection without penetrating orbital septum. Periorbital swelling without proptosis or EOM restriction.

diseases.name: Acute Mastoiditis
diseases.notes: Consider meningitis. Surgical debridement as indicated. Transition to PO once clinically improved.

diseases.name: Acute Bacterial Sinusitis
diseases.notes: Defined as persistent (>=10d), severe, or worsening symptoms. Augmentin formulations: 600mg/5mL or 1000/62.5 XR tablets.

diseases.name: Bacterial Tracheitis
diseases.notes: Tailor therapy to cultures. Consider alternate causes of symptoms.

diseases.name: Epiglottitis
diseases.notes: Provide airway support in OR/ICU setting with airway specialist.

diseases.name: Acute Otitis Media
diseases.notes: If >2 years, afebrile, no otalgia, borderline exam: consider symptomatic rx or safety net antibiotic prescription. 33% no bacterial origin.

diseases.name: Streptococcal Pharyngitis
diseases.notes: Culture before treating. GAS less common in children <3 years. Treatment decreases rheumatic fever 2/3.

diseases.name: Retropharyngeal Abscess
diseases.notes: Usually polymicrobial. Airway films in extension show increased prevertebral space. Consider CT to r/o extension. Transition to amoxicillin/clavulanate PO.

diseases.name: Aspiration Pneumonia
diseases.notes: High risk for aspiration: abnormal tone, impaired swallowing, poor cough, gastrostomy tube.

diseases.name: CAP - Infants/Preschool
diseases.notes: Viral pathogens responsible for majority of disease.

diseases.name: CAP - School Aged
diseases.notes: Consider atypical bacteria: Mycoplasma, C. pneumoniae. May add azithromycin.

diseases.name: CAP - Unimmunized
diseases.notes: For unimmunized patients at higher risk for H. influenzae.

diseases.name: Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

first_line.dose: 10 mg/kg x1 then 5 mg/kg x 4 days

diseases.notes: Azithromycin preferred for patients <1 month. Treat household and daycare contacts. Avoid antitussives.

diseases.name: Appendicitis / Bowel Perforation
diseases.notes: Antibiotic decision in conjunction with Surgery.

diseases.name: Clostridioides difficile Infection
diseases.notes: See C. diff testing algorithm. Do NOT perform test of cure. For fulminant: contact ID and/or GI. Metronidazole NOT recommended for chronic use due to neurotoxicity risk.

diseases.name: Salmonella Enteritis

first_line.indication: uncomplicated enteritis - associated with prolonged carriage

diseases.notes: No antibiotic therapy for uncomplicated enteritis - associated with prolonged carriage. Can be complicated by bacteremia, splenic abscess, osteomyelitis.

diseases.name: Shigella
diseases.notes: Treat hospitalized children, daycare attendees, food service workers, immunosuppressed. Illness usually self-limited (48-72 hours).

diseases.name: Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis
diseases.notes: Culture fluid before antibiotics if safe. Definitive therapy based on susceptibilities.

diseases.name: Peritonitis with Peritoneal Dialysis
diseases.notes: Antibiotics are added to dialysate in concentrations approximating serum. Intra-dialytic antibiotics available in orderset.

diseases.name: Simple Cystitis
diseases.notes: Simple cystitis = afebrile lower urinary tract infection.

diseases.name: Pyelonephritis
diseases.notes: Consider renal ultrasound if recurrent. If abnormal, consider VCUG. If severe cephalosporin allergy, may need cipro.

diseases.name: Febrile UTI
diseases.notes: See Infectious Disease - Neonatal Infections for neonates.

diseases.name: Cellulitis - Non-suppurative
diseases.notes: Non-suppurative = intact skin, no purulent drainage. Usually caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci.

diseases.name: Cellulitis - Suppurative/MRSA suspected
diseases.notes: Suppurative = purulent drainage present. MRSA coverage needed.

diseases.name: Skin Abscess, Furuncle, Carbuncle
diseases.notes: I&D is primary treatment. Send culture. Small furuncles: warm compresses. Larger: I&D + antibiotics. Simple abscess post-I&D may not need antibiotics per guidelines.

diseases.name: Lymphadenitis
diseases.notes: Common: GAS, S. aureus. Preschool: consider mycobacterial etiologies. Rabbit exposure: consider tularemia.

diseases.name: Cat Scratch Disease (Bartonella)
diseases.notes: Common in axillary/epitrochlear (46%), neck (26%), inguinal (17%). Send Bartonella serologies.

diseases.name: Necrotizing Fasciitis
diseases.notes: I&D, debridement, compartment release + antibiotics are mainstays. Suspect with acute swelling, erythema, tenderness, heat. Pain out of proportion to exam.

diseases.name: Impetigo / Infected Eczema
diseases.notes: Bullous impetigo: most likely toxin-producing S. aureus. Nonbullous: Staphylococcus spp and/or GAS.

diseases.name: Osteomyelitis (Acute Hematogenous)
diseases.notes: See CCHMC Acute Hematogenous Osteomyelitis Care Algorithm. Typically admitted to Hospital Medicine. IV to PO transition based on clinical improvement and inflammatory markers.

diseases.name: Septic Arthritis (<5 years)
diseases.notes: IV to PO switch after 72H of IV with clinical improvement, CRP decreased by 1/3 from peak.

diseases.name: Septic Arthritis (>=5 years)
diseases.notes: If clinically stable, consider oral step-down after 72h IV with improvement.

diseases.name: Septic Arthritis (Puncture Wound)
diseases.notes: Pseudomonas coverage needed for puncture wound-associated septic arthritis.

diseases.name: Cat Bite
diseases.notes: Indications for antibiotics: moderate/severe, crush injury, puncture wound, face/hand/genital, immunocompromised, near bone/joint. Prophylaxis 3-5 days, treatment 5-10 days.

diseases.name: Dog Bite
diseases.notes: Low risk (no infection signs, immunocompetent): no prophylaxis. Assess tetanus status.

diseases.name: Human Bite
diseases.notes: Higher infection risk than animal bites. Consider HIV, hepatitis testing if concern. Assess tetanus status.

diseases.name: Neonatal Sepsis
diseases.notes: Early onset (<7 days): GBS, E. coli, Listeria. Late onset (>=7 days): add CONS, S. aureus. Consider HSV if risk factors.

diseases.name: Neonatal Meningitis
diseases.notes: Duration typically 14-21 days depending on organism. Consider HSV testing and acyclovir.

diseases.name: Neonatal HSV
diseases.notes: Risk greatest <3 weeks. Greatest risk factor is primary maternal HSV at delivery. SEM: 14 days, CNS: 21 days, Disseminated: 21 days. All need suppressive therapy until 6 months after treatment.

diseases.name: Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC)
diseases.notes: Duration depends on severity. Medical NEC typically 7-10 days. Surgical NEC: 10-14 days post-operative.

diseases.name: Neonatal UTI
diseases.notes: Consider sepsis workup in febrile neonates with UTI. Duration typically 7-14 days.
